right we're only seven seconds into this

you can find lamb ribs every lamb has

to work with any rib babyback spare ribs
beef ribs you name it but like I said
I'm gonna use lamb ribs and here they
are I have two racks kind of similar
thickness to a baby back and the first
phase of this recipe is to let this sit
overnight soaking in a sesame and root
beer marinade but the procedure is going
to be a little bit different than just
dumping everything in a bag like we
usually do
we're going to actually apply the sesame
mixture first and then introduce the
root beer so into a small bowl I'm going
to pour some toasted sesame oil and then
we're going to add a whole bunch of
sriracha or any kind of chili paste or
chilli sauce and a good amount of salt
and I'm going to take my pastry brush
I'm going to mix that up and what we're
going to do is we're going to brush that
on both sides of our ribs and I'm just
doing this on foil so don't mess up my
cutting board or pan this is actually
going to go in a bag next so we're going
to apply that mixture liberally to the
meat and my theory here is that sesame
oil will adhere to the fat and the ribs
much better if we apply it like this and
then pour the liquid in versus just
mixing everything together and like most
of my theories I can't prove it but I
think this is better
and speaking of theories you'll have to
check the blog post to find out why I
didn't poke or peel the membrane all
right so check that out later and once
all that's brushed down we're going to
go ahead and transfer that into a
sealable plastic bag heavy duty please
and once we have it in there we're going
to pour in a bottle of root beer now of
course any brand is going to work and I
don't know anything about this
particular brand but I always choose
based on which label looks like the kind
they used back in the olden times so I
went with this one we're going to dump
that in and at that point we're going to
seal up the bag and place that in the
refrigerator for 12 to 24 hours alright
so basically overnight and that's going
to allow that root beer and sesame
flavors to permeate the meat and as some
of you may have already realized this is
based on a recipe we did a couple years
ago for braised lamb that we did in
sesame in root beer for extra credit can
you tell me which celebrity chef I stole
the idea from so this is a flavor

record of being awesome okay so we're
going to leave that overnight in the
fridge then
stay we're ready to cook I'm going to
place a large piece of heavy-duty foil

up I'm going to season both sides with
salt and pepper and then we're going to
place a piece of foil on top but before
I do I'm going to put a piece of
parchment paper on top of the meats and
this is basically an homage to an old
chef I used to work for that always put
parchment on top of the meat before he
wrapped it he said it kept him moister
and while there's no scientific proof
for that I still do it once in a while
I'm going to put another piece of foil
on top of that and then we're going to
bring up the four sides like that so we
have it nicely encased and at that point
we're going to place that in a preheated
250 degree oven for about two to
two-and-a-half hours or until it's
almost getting fork-tender all right so
we're going to put that in the oven
we're going to set our timer in the

and I'm going to have you boil at for
about five minutes or so until it
reduces by about half and then just turn

right so just set that aside
by this time the ribs have been in about

we're ready for final production so
